head.title: Patience Doesn't Pay For Social Security

hedline.hl1: Patience Doesn't Pay For Social Security

abstract.p: Charles A Miller letter responds to May 28 Economic View column; points out that many people are not in position to wait until age 70 before taking Social Security retirement benefits (M)

block.p: Should people in their 60's -- who are in good health and whose parents lived long lives -- ''rationally choose to defer'' receiving Social Security, as one scholar advised in the column?
Some people, however, have no choice; they need the money to live on, or to help out their relatives. It can hardly be irrational to pass it up.

The column also saw a ''second irrational tendency'' among people drawing both paychecks and benefit checks: to spend the pension money instead of saving it for the future. But again, as has been widely reported, many Americans are in no position to save.
They really need money, and need it whenever they can get it.
CHARLES A. MILLER New Market, Va., June 2
